pullRequest.body:
This introduces a file `Classifier.lean` defining the notion `Classifier C` of subobject classifier in any category `C` with a terminal object, following Section I.3 of "Sheaves in Geometry and Logic" [MM92]. This is related to but independent from #21281, because our definition associates a characteristic map to every _subobject_ rather than every _monomorphism_. Adopting this "extensional" rather than "intensional" definition allows us to formalize the proof of Proposition 1 in [MM92, Section I.3] (`hasClassifier_isRepresentable_iff`), that `C` has a subobject classifier if and only if the subobjects presheaf `sub C` is representable.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [5d6f875ecb](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22245/commits/5d6f875ecbcf8d57f37e586ba8911206090bcacc)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Subobject.Classifier` (new file)|613|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Classifier`
`+ HasClassifier`
`+ IsClassifier`
`+ cmap`
`+ cmap_compr`
`+ compr`
`+ compr_cmap`
`+ compr_isPullback`
`+ isPullback_eq`
`+ isPullback_eq_mk`
`+ isPullback_mk`
`+ isRepresentable_hasClassifier_iff`
`+ mk_arrow_mk`
`+ of_iso1`
`+ of_iso3`
`+ pullback_obj`
`+ pullback_obj_representative`
`+ sub`
`+ truth`
`+ unique_eq`
`+ χ_`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

A significant part of this PR duplicates #21281 (which shall soon be merged). You may contribute with the relation between the data/existence of a classifier in the sense of #21281, and the representability of the "subobject" functor, but you should certainly introduce a few auxiliary definitions/lemmas in order to provide a suitable API.

> A significant part of this PR duplicates #21281 (which shall soon be merged). You may contribute with the relation between the data/existence of a classifier in the sense of #21281, and the representability of the "subobject" functor, but you should certainly introduce a few auxiliary definitions/lemmas in order to provide a suitable API.

Can you be more specific as to what parts are duplicated? I think most of this formalization exploits some definitions in `CategoryTheory.Subobject`, which is not the case in #21281.

Concerning the relationship with the "intensional" classifier in the sense of #21281, I think going from intensional to extensional (my definition) should be quite easy, but not the other way around. I see two possible ways:

1. To avoid confusion, I just remove my definitions of `IsClassifier`, `Classifier` and `HasClassifier`, and build the other definitions based on them directly from those of #21281;
2. I keep both variants in separate namespaces (`CategoryTheory` for the intensional version, and `CategoryTheory.Subobject` for the extensional one), and add an API to build a `CategoryTheory.Subobject.Classifier` from a `CategoryTheory.Classifier`.

(1) would ensure "automatically" that we use the same naming conventions, avoiding potential duplication and making for a shorter contribution. (2) could be useful in situations where one wants only the weaker notion of extensional subobject classifier. For instance, the bijection between monos and their characteristic map trivially gives a bijection between subobjects and their characteristic map, but this is not true in the other direction.

I would argue in favor of (2) because it can be used to produce more general results requiring fewer assumptions. Unfortunately there does not seem to be anyway to directly share code with #21281 (e.g. with structure inheritance).

It does not seem reasonable to me to have two separate API for the same mathematical notion. `Subobject X` and `MonoOver X` are equivalent categories: I do not see any serious difference between quantifying on `x : Subobject X` (as you do) or on monomorphisms `U ⟶ X` (as in #21281).
My understanding is that one can use the `Classifier` structure in #21281 and introduce a definition `Classifier.representableBy` saying that the functor of subobjects is representable.

I am a bit surprised that you would say they are the same mathematical notion just because there is an equivalence of categories, but maybe that's because I am a constructivist. Or is it the case that in Lean, every essentially surjective functor is split essentially surjective (see [the nLab](https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/equivalence+of+categories#idea))?

Anyway I am fine trying to follow route (1), but I am not sure about what statement you have in mind for `Classifier.representableBy`. If it is `HasClassifier C -> sub.representableBy Ω`, then this is just a direct corollary of my `hasClassifier_isRepresentable_iff` theorem. Should I still add it?
What I am suggesting is given the data and properties `c : Classifier C`, define a term `c.representableBy` saying that `c.Ω` (equipped with `c.truth`) represents the subobject functor.
So a term `representableBy : forall (c : Classifier C), sub.RepresentableBy c.Ω`?

I have now implemented the required changes, by merging the results originally written in `CategoryTheory/Subobject/Classifier.lean` into `CategoryTheory/Topos/Classifier.lean` (as well as a few other files so that more general lemmas are put in the appropriate places).

> I have now implemented the required changes, by merging the results originally written in `CategoryTheory/Subobject/Classifier.lean` into `CategoryTheory/Topos/Classifier.lean` (as well as a few other files so that more general lemmas are put in the appropriate places).

I do not know what happened with your branch regarding the use of git? but something messy happened.

I would suggest creating a separate PR which only adds the definition of the "subobject functor". This should go in a separate file in the folder `CategoryTheory.Subobject`.

pullRequest.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Subobject): add formalization of subobject classifier
